author: Gerry Smith
title: Moderna sales get lift from early nod for newest COVID shot
text:
Moderna delivered better-than-expected profit and sales in the third quarter after an early start to sales of this season‚Äôs COVID boosters.
The company‚Äôs latest COVID shot was approved three weeks earlier than last year, according to a statement Thursday, helping drive product sales up 3.6 percent. Moderna still foresees 2024 product sales of $3 billion to $3.5 billion.
It‚Äôs unclear whether Moderna will sell as many COVID vaccines as it did last year, but it looks like a ‚Äúdurable and sizable market,‚Äù Moderna CFO Jamey Mock said in an interview. ‚ÄúIt proves that there‚Äôs certainly a patient population that wants to be protected against COVID.‚Äù
Investors have been spooked since the pandemic by fading sales of COVID vaccines and a slow rollout for Moderna‚Äôs only other product, an RSV vaccine. The RSV shot was cleared in May, after customers had ordered rival products, and had just $10 million in sales in the quarter.
Moderna‚Äôs shares fell more than 3 percent. The stock has fallen 48 percent this year through Wednesday‚Äôs close. It plunged in September after the company forecast 2025 sales below analysts‚Äô expectations and pushed back its target to break even by two years to 2028.
Advertisement

author: laurynas776
title: CAREER MODE 2 BUGS
text:
een uur geleden
Dear EA Support,
I am experiencing two issues in Career Mode in EA Sports FC 25:
Youth Scout Reports: When my youth scouts return with their reports, I am unable to open them. Every time I try, I get a screen that just shows "null." Despite this, I know that the players are being scouted and their information is available in the system, but I cannot view it due to this bug.
Player Growth Indicators: I have noticed that the "+" or "-" indicators next to players' ratings in the Squad Hub (which show how much their stats have grown or declined) are no longer visible. The players are still growing, but I can‚Äôt see the exact amount of progress as I used to.
Could you please assist me with resolving these issues? Any help or guidance would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your support.
Best regards,
Probeer eerst deze stappen als je problemen ondervindt bij het verbinden met een EA-game.
We controleren of jij het bent door je een code te sturen voor je vertrouwde apparaten.

author: Courtney Travis
title: Colossal winter storm to unleash snow, ice, severe weather from Plains to mid-Atlantic
text:
By Courtney Travis ,
3 hours ago Over a dozen states could see travel-snarling ice and snow, while other areas brace for a new round of severe weather as a major storm tracks across the United States.
A massive storm is expected to bring both wintry and severe weather to millions of Americans as early as this weekend, AccuWeather meteorologists warn.
"Over a dozen states are forecast to be impacted by one or more aspects of this storm," said AccuWeather Meteorologist Brandon Buckingham.
The storm emerging from the Rockies late on Saturday is forecast to deliver a far-reaching swath of ice and snow across the middle of the country while rain and thunderstorms spread across the southern tier of the United States.
Snow, ice to sweep Central states this weekend The intrusion of bitterly cold, Arctic air into the middle of the country will set the stage for wintry weather in the Plains, starting on Saturday. Snowflakes could fly as far south as northern Oklahoma. Meanwhile, enough snow to shovel and plow will extend for about 1,000 miles from central Nebraska to Ohio through early Monday.
"The accumulating snow, which could approach or exceed a half of a foot is expected to bring travel to a stand still in places like Kansas City, St. Louis, Indianapolis and Cincinnati," said Buckingham.
An AccuWeather Local StormMax‚Ñ¢ of 30 inches is most likely to occur somewhere from northern Missouri to west-central Illinois.
Just to the south, parts of Kansas, Missouri, Illinois and Indiana are forecast to experience ice mixing with snow during the storm, which can limit the amount of total snow accumulation. A difficult battle between warm and cold air will determine exactly how much snow, versus ice, falls in some areas like Kansas City and St. Louis in Missouri. A change of just 20-30 miles farther south with the track of the storm could result in much more snow and less ice.
"A major freezing rain event is expected to unfold, making for dangerous ice accretions across the northern Ozarks, middle Mississippi Valley and Ohio Valley this weekend," Buckingham said.
Communities from Springfield, Missouri, to Lexington, Kentucky, could be in for a substantial amount of ice that brings dangerous travel conditions. Additionally, this much ice can weigh down tree limbs, increasing the chance for tree damage and resulting power outages.
"Power outages, extensive tree damage and lengthy travel days will be a concern in the worst-hit areas," said Buckingham.
The power could be out for several days in some communities when dangerously cold air invades in the wake of the storm. There may be a great need for shelters to be set up to account for the affected population.
Even a trace of icing can lead to a coating on cars and cause slippery spots, especially on bridges and overpasses. Untreated roads or sidewalks could be slick for much of the weekend.
Far-reaching cold following behind the storm could pave the way for more wintry weather in the same zones as January continues.
Severe thunderstorms to spark again in southern US Some of the same states still reeling from last weekend's severe weather will once again need to watch for severe thunderstorms with the coming storm.
The potent storm will bring a clash of cold air in the Plains, and warm moisture from the Gulf of Mexico will help to fuel the severe weather chances on Sunday.
"A line of thunderstorms is expected to develop across eastern Texas Sunday afternoon, strengthening as they move into Louisiana, Arkansas, Mississippi and Alabama through Sunday night," said AccuWeather Meteorologist Gwen Fieweger.
Fieweger also warns that many storms in the Interstate 10 and 20 corridors could bring damaging wind gusts, hail and flooding downpours, but a few thunderstorms may also be capable of producing a few tornadoes.
Have the app? Unlock AccuWeather Alerts‚Ñ¢ with Premium+ Disruptive snow, ice in Northeast and mid-Atlantic to start week After dumping snow and ice across the center of the country, portions of the East Coast will be next to endure the winter weather.
"Residents and visitors across the mid-Atlantic states are also in line to deal with the first winter storm in quite some time, posing a major risk to travel between Sunday night and Monday evening," Buckingham warned.
Accumulating snow is expected to reach as far north as central Pennsylvania and extend southward through northern Virginia. Major metro areas such as Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington, D.C., can expect several inches of accumulation.
"The western suburbs of Baltimore and Washington, D.C., could have snowfall totals nearing half a foot by the end of the storm," said Buckingham. The higher terrain in West Virginia and western Maryland are the most likely to see totals near the AccuWeather Local StormMax‚Ñ¢ of 15 inches.
Slippery conditions can be expected as the storm moves into the area, disrupting travel. The heaviest snow late Sunday night and into Monday morning could lead to longer commute times in bustling hubs like Philadelphia.
Locations across central Virginia and the Carolinas are unlikely to see much snow accumulation, but cold air will create sleet and freezing rain instead.
Sleet and freezing rain are likely to be most extensive near the Appalachians, but the ice could reach the beaches of Virginia late on Sunday night, continuing into Monday before the storm moves offshore.
Lingering cold air in the wake of this storm will likely keep any snow or ice around for several days after the end of the storm. The lack of warm air will also leave open the door for more wintry storms to sweep through the region into mid-January.
Want next-level safety, ad-free? Unlock advanced, hyperlocal severe weather alerts when you subscribe to Premium+ on the AccuWeather app . AccuWeather Alerts ‚Ñ¢ are prompted by our expert meteorologists who monitor and analyze dangerous weather risks 24/7 to keep you and your family safer.
6

author: Redazione Web
title: Michael Schumacher ¬´portato in macchina per stimolare il cervello con rumori familiari¬ª
text: [Schumacher](/t/schumacher) torna a bordo di una Mercedes Amg, ma non √® il lieto fine che tutti gli appassionati di [Formula 1](/t/formula-1) sperano da tanto. Lex pilota √® stato fatto salire sulla vettura per cercare di stimolare il cervello con suoni a lui familiari. [Schumacher, la verit√† del fratello Ralf: ¬´Grazie a qualche cura moderna qualcosa si √® potuto fare, ma niente √® come prima¬ª](/persone/schumacher_news_oggi_verita_fratello_ralf_nulla_come_prima-7836783.html) L'incidente di Schumacher di 10 anni fa Dieci anni fa, sulle nevi delle Alpi francesi a Meribel, Michael cadeva sulla neve durante una vacanza sulla neve con la famiglia. La camera sportiva che indossava sul casco ha perforato e il cranio del tedesco che √® stato trasportato con urgenza in ospedale ed √® rimasto in coma per sei mesi. Da quel giorno le sue condizioni non sono mai state rese note, n√© tantomeno aggiornamenti sul suo stato di salute con la famiglia che ha mantenuto il massimo riserbo. Ora Schumi √® assistito nella sua villa a Gland sul lago di Ginevra in Svizzera da una squadra di specialisti, circa 15 persone, che lo seguono a turno 24 ore su 24.

author: Adam McCulloch
title: Most businesses will need to adjust wages in April
text:
Most businesses will have to adjust their wage structures in the wake of this April‚Äôs national minimum wage rises.
Organisations will have to consider the effect on employee retention and overall pay differentials, said an analysis by HR insight firm Brightmine.
Brightmine‚Äôs data shows nearly 60% of organisations will need to raise wages, with three-quarters expecting challenges around pay gaps between job levels.
From 1 April, 2025, the national living wage for those aged 21 and over will rise to ¬£12.21 per hour, while the national minimum wage for 18-20 year olds will increase to ¬£10 per hour and the rate for 16-17 year olds and apprentices will be ¬£7.55 per hour.
Businesses will need to head off the risk of employee friction over the changes, said Sheila Attwood, HR insights and data lead at Brightmine.
She added: ‚ÄúOne of the key challenges is the impact on pay differentials, as lower pay bands catch up with the next job level.
‚ÄúNearly three-quarters (74.3%) of affected organisations expect pay differentials to be squeezed, which can create pay compression issues and potential dissatisfaction among more experienced employees.‚Äù
She said those organisations that had anticipated the changes were reviewing their pay structures, either by adjusting salaries across multiple levels, defining minimum differentials, or even reshaping their grading systems. ‚ÄúOthers are exploring alternative solutions such as upskilling employees, offering bonuses, or enhancing benefits to retain staff and maintain motivation,‚Äù said Attwood.
‚ÄúEmployers need a clear strategy to manage these changes, ensuring they remain competitive while maintaining fair and structured pay progression.‚Äù
For companies looking to alter wage structures and increase pay, Recruitment and Employment Confederation chief executive Neil Carberry said that, based on poll results from February, business sentiment had improved this spring. This was despite the impact of the national insurance hike hanging over companies ‚Äúlike a fog‚Äù.
He said REC survey respondents were now optimistic about their intentions to hire permanent staff in the short term.
Carberry said employers ‚Äúfelt the most confident about medium-term permanent hiring (the next four to 12 months). Medium-sized organisations (50-249 employees) were clearly the most optimistic about permanent hiring‚Äù.

author: Mark Gruenberg
title: Supreme Court‚Äôs sorry record on elections is bad news for 2024
text: The famed Chicago columnist Finley Peter Dunne, better known as ‚ÄúMr. Dooley,‚Äù once said to his pal Hennissy, in Chicago Irish dialect, that ‚ÄúNo matter whither th‚Äô Constitution follows th‚Äô flag or not, th‚Äô Supreme Court follows th‚Äô election returns.‚Äù Well, this Supreme Court, and specifically the Republican majority that has dominated it for the last half-century, doesn‚Äôt follow the election returns. It‚Äîpardon the expression‚Äîscrews up U.S. election returns. And it‚Äôs not done yet. Who benefits? The ultra-rich and the criminal capitalist class. Who suffers? Workers, women, voters of color, the young, the old, and the rest of us. Starting with Buckley vs Valeo in 1976, the justices have systematically dismantled all protections against corrupt corporate influence on elections, eliminated voting rights, tossed out limits on and disclosure of campaign contributions and spending, and, most recently, [legalized corruption](https://www.peoplesworld.org/article/supreme-court-oks-payoffs-for-politicians-doing-corporate-bidding/). They even picked a president. Remember Bush vs Gore in 2000? The court stopped the vote count in Florida, with Republican George W. Bush in the lead. Bush‚Äôs corporate backers wanted that. The Republican-named justices cloak some of their rulings in the garb of freedom of speech, invoking the Constitution‚Äôs First Amendment. But‚Äîand this is important for workers‚Äîfree speech for whom? Because when the justices turn the corporate treasuries loose on political campaigns, when they eliminate limits on individual contributions and campaign self-funders when they let shady corporate donors hide behind SuperPACs and supposed ‚Äúnon-profit‚Äù organizations, when they bar common methods of absentee voting, when they reject partisan redistricting plans unless they‚Äôre racially motivated, and on and on and on, guess who gets frozen out? Let‚Äôs start with Buckley, and you‚Äôll see what we‚Äôre talking about: That 1976 decision said limits on election spending are unconstitutional. GOP Chief Justice Warren Burger‚Äôs court ruled campaign spending limits ‚Äúcontravene free speech because a restriction on spending for political communication necessarily reduces the quantity of expression.‚Äù Yes, it does, but only for those who don‚Äôt have the dollars to spend‚Ä¶like you and me. We, not the big givers and spenders, get no say. The money men, and they‚Äôre almost all white men, do. Even one justice who went along, Democratic-named Byron ‚ÄúWhizzer‚Äù White, recognized the danger. White warned his colleagues the post-Watergate Congress ‚Äúlegitimately recognized unlimited election spending as a mortal danger against which effective preventive and curative steps must be taken.‚Äù But for White, and the others, supposed ‚Äúfreedom of speech‚Äù trumped all. Fast forward 24 years, to Bush vs Gore. Now, they could very well do it a second time in the 2024 election. Guess who their pick will be. Regardless of how they rule, the jurists have legitimized the delay-delay-delay tactics of Republican nominee Donald Trump. That convicted felon, womanizer, and white supremacist demands unlimited immunity from federal prosecution for any crime, in and out of the White House he once inhabited, forever. Just the delay alone‚Äîwe‚Äôll repeat that, just the delay alone ‚Äì lets Trump run again, without fear of prosecution. If he wins, he‚Äôll institute his ‚Äúdictatorship on day one‚Äù vow. Nobody believes he‚Äôd stop then. First, Trump would shut down federal prosecutions he faces. Then he‚Äôd pardon his Capitol invaders. But back to the Supreme Court and what it‚Äôs let loose upon us. First, 14 years ago, came Citizens United. That unleashed corporate treasuries, with no limits and no accountability, again in the name of free speech. A right-wing operative, seeking to finance an anti-Hillary Clinton borderline slander, brought the case because his film could be deemed an illegal corporate contribution. It cost too much for the limits. Voila! No more limits. Justice John Paul Stevens, leading the dissenters, called Citizens United ‚Äúa rejection of the common sense of the American people, who recognized a need to prevent corporations from undermining self-government.‚Äù The Republican court majority didn‚Äôt listen. Two years later, the justices turned individual campaign donors loose, in a case involving a GOP megadonor from Alabama. In legal briefs, the party gleefully backed him‚Äîand won. The U.S. people lost. Then the court gutted key provisions of the Voting Rights Act, especially its enforcement in states, cities, and elsewhere with histories of discrimination. Who got hurt? Women, students, people of color, workers, the poor, and the old. How fast did we lose rights? The Rev. William Barber II, co-chair of the Poor People‚Äôs Campaign, said after the justices issued that Holder decision, the gerrymandered GOP-run North Carolina legislature took only ‚Äú45 minutes‚Äù to disenfranchise thousands of voters in his home state. Speaking of gerrymandering, the Republican court majority ignores it in most cases. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a political question,‚Äù they declare. Two exceptions: - (a) If it‚Äôs based on race, not politics, and - (b) If it‚Äôs literally shoved in the justices‚Äô faces. That happened in Alabama and Louisiana, but not‚Äîthe justices said‚Äîin the two Carolinas. Pre-Holder, the Voting Rights Act would have forced the feds to toss all gerrymandering, including both Carolinas and Florida and Texas and Georgia and‚Ä¶and‚Ä¶.and‚Ä¶and. Not now. Not content with letting politicians choose their voters, the justices also make it harder for voters to vote. One ruling rejected common methods of collecting absentee ballots, in a case from Arizona. And on June 26, they dealt more carnage to our elections. The court majority [legalized post-election bribery](https://www.peoplesworld.org/article/supreme-court-oks-payoffs-for-politicians-doing-corporate-bidding/), though the Republican justices don‚Äôt call it that. They call such payments ‚Äúgratuities.‚Äù Bribes are illegal, the justices said. In most cases, gratuities aren‚Äôt, Trump-named Justice Brett Kavanaugh wrote. When they are, Kavanaugh called them ‚Äútwo separate crimes‚Äù with ‚Äútwo different sets of elements.‚Äù The five other Republican-named justices agreed. Even Trump knows there‚Äôs no difference. ‚ÄúWhen you give, they do whatever the hell you want them to do,‚Äù he said of politicians nine years ago. That‚Äôs why Trump, now a politician, promised a quid pro quo of lower taxes and less regulation to oil barons when he met them at Mar-a-Lago in May‚Äîif they gave his campaign a billion bucks. The other June ruling, in a small win for sanity, says social media has editorial control over its content. The right wanted to dictate what you see and hear. It lost the case on technical grounds. Of course, the right and the GOP now manipulate social media to toe their line, and shut workers and others out. When they brought the case, they were screaming about corporate censorship via algorithms and government pressure through complaints. You don‚Äôt hear them screaming now, not when right-wing multibillionaire Elon Musk imposes his will on Twitter/X. Trump isn‚Äôt on the High Court. Yet its justices, including the three he named, by their delays, impose the possibility of a Trump dictatorship, and no more free and fair elections, upon all of us. Does anybody seriously doubt that after all his disproven cries of fraud in 2020 and others as far back as 2016, Trump won‚Äôt scream fraud again this year? And if voters elect him, he‚Äôll ensure there‚Äôs no future fraud against him. He ‚Äì and his Trumpites in lower-level offices, from election boards to state courts to governors ‚Äì will rig the vote. For Trump. Thank you, U.S. Supreme Court. As with all op-eds published by People‚Äôs World, this article reflects the views of its author. We hope you appreciated this article. At People‚Äôs World, we believe news and information should be free and accessible to all, but we need your help. Our journalism is free of corporate influence and paywalls because we are totally reader-supported. Only you, our readers and supporters, make this possible. If you enjoy reading People‚Äôs World and the stories we bring you, please [support our work by donating or becoming a monthly sustainer today]. Thank you!

author: TV
title: Un afortunado se lleva 500.000 euros con el Cup√≥n Diario de la ONCE de este jueves
text: Un afortunado se lleva 500.000 euros con el Cup√≥n Diario de la ONCE de este jueves Sorteo 19 de septiembre ¬∑ Conoce y comprueba los n√∫meros premiados del sorteo de la ONCE celebrado este 19 de septiembreSecciones Servicios Destacamos Sorteo 19 de septiembre ¬∑ Conoce y comprueba los n√∫meros premiados del sorteo de la ONCE celebrado este 19 de septiembreTV Jueves, 19 de septiembre 2024, 21:41 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Opciones para compartir El [sorteo del Cup√≥n Diario de la ONCE ](/sorteos/la-once/sorteo-once-cupon-diario-miercoles-deja-premio-20240918213856-nt.html)celebrado este [jueves 19 de septiembre](/sorteos/la-primitiva/primitiva-jueves-deja-nuevo-millonario-jugador-lleva-20240919223823-nt.html), ha vuelto a poner en juego decenas de [premios ](/sorteos/loteria-nacional/loteria-nacional-jueves-deja-primer-premio-valencia-20240919213758-nt.html)por la geograf√≠a nacional como suele ser habitual a lo largo de la semana. Cabe recordar que el Cup√≥n Diario de la ONCE pone en juego un premio de 500.000 euros al n√∫mero m√°s la serie y 49 premios de 35.000 euros a las cinco cifras del n√∫mero premiado, entre otros. Estos son los [n√∫meros premiados ](/sorteos/eurodreams/jugador-lleva-sueldo-2000-euros-mes-anos-20240919214929-nt.html)en el sorteo del Cup√≥n Diario de la ONCE de este jueves: 84708 Reintegro: 8 y 8 Serie: 032 Noticia relacionada 1 premio de 500.000 ‚Ç¨ a las 5 cifras y serie. 49 premios de 35.000 ‚Ç¨ a las 5 cifras. 450 premios de 250 ‚Ç¨ a las 4 primeras cifras. 450 premios de 250 ‚Ç¨ a las 4 √∫ltimas cifras. 4.500 premios de 25 ‚Ç¨ a las 3 primeras cifras. 4.500 premios de 25 ‚Ç¨ a las 3 √∫ltimas cifras. 45.000 premios de 6 ‚Ç¨ a las 2 primeras cifras. 44.550 premios de 6 ‚Ç¨ a las 2 √∫ltimas cifras. 445.500 premios de 2 ‚Ç¨ a la primera cifra. 405.000 premios de 2 ‚Ç¨ a la √∫ltima cifra. En un mismo cup√≥n no son acumulables dos o m√°s premios. Historias de millonarios Javier Espinosa llevaba casi toda su vida apostando por los mismos n√∫meros en la Primitiva, una tradici√≥n iniciada por sus padres, hasta que la suerte llam√≥ a su puerta en 2019 y se llev√≥ [80 millones de euros de la Primitiva](/las_provincias_2017/noticias/201901/06/sorteos/la-primitiva/claves-numero-loteria.xml). La combinaci√≥n ganadora estuvo formada por los n√∫meros 7, 13, 23, 40, 41 y 49, el complementario fue el 16 y el n√∫mero clave (reintegro), el 3. Estos 8 n√∫meros cambiaron la historia de un vecino de Bonrep√≥s que hab√≠a sellado su boleto en Tarvernes Blanques, junto a Valencia. Javier ten√≠a un negocio familiar dedicado a la venta de materiales de fontaner√≠a, con m√°s de 25 a√±os de historia y que hab√≠a pasado por una grave crisis durante a√±os. Cuando Javier llam√≥ a su novia para contarle la noticia, ella, incr√©dula, le dijo antes de colgar que fuera a los premios Oscar por su buena interpretaci√≥n. Javier encarg√≥ un Ferrari, un sue√±o de la infancia, y poco despu√©s se construy√≥ una casa en Bonrep√≥s. Sus vecinos cuentan que ya tiene media docena de b√≥lidos y que ha entrado por derecho propio en el selecto 'Club Ferrari' gracias al dinero de la Primitiva. La historia de Rachel Kennedy y Liam McCrohan es de tener mala suerte. La pareja de Inglaterra estuvo muy cerca de ganar 182 millones de euros. Los j√≥venes estudiantes participaban siempre en el sorteo de Euromillones y, adem√°s, apostaban siempre por los mismos n√∫meros. No fallaban ning√∫n d√≠a, de hecho, ten√≠an configurado una plataforma con la que pod√≠an comprar autom√°ticamente boletos cada semana. When your Mrs decides to not play the EuroMillons... and all 7 of her usual numbers come upüò≠üò≠¬£182M Liam M (@LiamMccrohan)[pic.twitter.com/3iXMo38wQG][March 1, 2021] Sin embargo, un viernes no lo hicieron dado que su cuenta bancaria se encontraba sin fondos. ¬´No pensamos que iban a salir¬ª, contaron al medio brit√°nico The Sun. Estaban equivocados. Cuando revisaron la aplicaci√≥n, recibieron una notificaci√≥n con los n√∫meros con los que siempre jugaban, que estaban configurados. Y vieron que eran los que se hab√≠an llevado el mayor premio. As√≠, se privaron de embolsarse 182 millones de euros, que era la cifra exacta del bote. Rufino se convirti√≥ en el vecino m√°s famoso de Valuengo, un peque√±o pueblo de Jerez tras ganar el Gordo de la Primitiva. Se hizo con 5 millones cuatrocientos mil euros. Lo m√°s curioso es c√≥mo se enter√≥ de que era millonario: en el bar y por casualidad. Rufino se tomaba un caf√© en el bar de siempre. Entre los clientes, surgi√≥ la conversaci√≥n que a alguien de la localidad le hab√≠a tocado el premio del Gordo de la Primitiva. El camarero del local se ofreci√≥ a comprobar el boleto de Rufino: ¬´El del Gordo eres t√∫¬ª. Y a partir de ah√≠, incredulidad general. Nadie en el bar se lo cre√≠a, ni el propio ganador. Rufino tuvo un accidente en la empresa en la que trabajaba que le cost√≥ tres dedos de una mano y la incapacidad laboral. [Jane Park gan√≥ el Euromillones con 17 a√±os](https://www.lasprovincias.es/sorteos/euromillones/triste-historia-ganadora-euromillones-20190504082822-nt.html). Ahora, cuatro a√±os despu√©s, ha desvelado que lo que pensaba que le iba a mejorar la vida, ha conseguido todo lo contrario. De hecho, desea demandar a la Loter√≠a por ¬´arruinarle¬ª la vida. La joven tuvo suerte porque gan√≥ el premio con el primer boleto que compr√≥. La cifra con la que se hizo fue, exactamente, de 1.175.000 euros. Seg√∫n ha contado en una entrevista del diario Mirror, el premio le hizo perder la cabeza y derroch√≥ el dinero en ropa de dise√±o, coches y operaciones est√©ticas. Ahora, reconoce que preferir√≠a no haber ganado el Euromillons porque su vida ser√≠a ¬´m√°s f√°cil¬ª. Tal y como ha confesado, a pesar de que tiene mucho dinero su vida est√° ¬´vac√≠a¬ª y le cuesta mucho encontrar una pareja que no se interese, √∫nicamente, por su dinero. Daniela pas√≥ del cielo al infierno en cuesti√≥n de segundos. Cuenta que, como todos los a√±os, su madre le regal√≥ a ella y a sus hermanos un [boleto de la ONCE](https://www.lasprovincias.es/temas/generales/el-cuponazo-sorteo-once.html) del sorteo del 1 de enero. Lo compr√≥ en la Avenida del Oeste, el puesto m√°s cercano al Mercado Central. Una tradici√≥n familiar. Nunca perd√≠an la esperanza de que alg√∫n d√≠a fueran los afortunados. Y por fin, el boleto premiado con el n√∫mero 8290 estaba entre sus manos. A la mujer le hab√≠an tocado 400.000 euros.
